briefdescription.para: how to perform the search in search_core
The product quantizer used to encode the vectors.
parameters used for the polysemous training

detaileddescription.para: set if the Index does not require training, or if training is done already

briefdescription.para: type of metric this index uses for search

memberdef.argsstring: (int d, size_t M, size_t nbits, MetricType metric=METRIC_L2)
memberdef.name: IndexPQ

briefdescription.para: number of bit per subvector index

detaileddescription.para: Constructor.

parameterdescription.para: number of bit per subvector index

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x) override
memberdef.name: train

detaileddescription.para: Perform training on a representative set of vectors

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x) override
memberdef.name: add

detaileddescription.para: Add n vectors of dimension d to the index.

Vectors are implicitly assigned labels ntotal .. ntotal + n - 1 This function slices the input vectors in chuncks smaller than blocksize_add and calls add_core.
x
input matrix, size n * d

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, idx_t k, float *distances, idx_t *labels) const override
memberdef.name: search

detaileddescription.para: query n vectors of dimension d to the index.
return at most k vectors. If there are not enough results for a query, the result array is padded with -1s.

parameterdescription.para: input vectors to search, size n * d
output labels of the NNs, size n*k

memberdef.argsstring: () override
memberdef.name: reset

briefdescription.para: removes all elements from the database.

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t i0, idx_t ni, float *recons) const override
memberdef.name: reconstruct_n

detaileddescription.para: Reconstruct vectors i0 to i0 + ni - 1

this function may not be defined for some indexes
recons
reconstucted vector (size ni * d)

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t key, float *recons) const override
memberdef.name: reconstruct

detaileddescription.para: Reconstruct a stored vector (or an approximation if lossy coding)

this function may not be defined for some indexes
key
id of the vector to reconstruct
recons
reconstucted vector (size d)

memberdef.argsstring: (const IDSelector &sel) override
memberdef.name: remove_ids

detaileddescription.para: removes IDs from the index. Not supported by all indexes. Returns the number of elements removed.

memberdef.argsstring: () const override
memberdef.name: sa_code_size

detaileddescription.para: size of the produced codes in bytes

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, uint8_t *bytes) const override
memberdef.name: sa_encode

detaileddescription.para: encode a set of vectors

parameterdescription.para: output encoded vectors, size n * sa_code_size()

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const uint8_t *bytes, float *x) const override
memberdef.name: sa_decode

detaileddescription.para: encode a set of vectors

parameterdescription.para: input encoded vectors, size n * sa_code_size()

memberdef.argsstring: () const override
memberdef.name: get_distance_computer

detaileddescription.para: Get a DistanceComputer (defined in AuxIndexStructures) object for this kind of index.
DistanceComputer is implemented for indexes that support random access of their vectors.

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, idx_t k, float *distances, idx_t *labels) const
memberdef.name: search_core_polysemous

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, idx_t nb, const float *xb, int64_t *dist_histogram)
memberdef.name: hamming_distance_histogram

detaileddescription.para:
prepare query for a polysemous search, but instead of computing the result, just get the histogram of Hamming distances. May be computed on a provided dataset if xb != NULL
dist_histogram
(M * nbits + 1)

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, int32_t *dis) const
memberdef.name: hamming_distance_table

detaileddescription.para: compute pairwise distances between queries and database

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, const idx_t *xids)
memberdef.name: add_with_ids

detaileddescription.para: Same as add, but stores xids instead of sequential ids.
The default implementation fails with an assertion, as it is not supported by all indexes.

parameterdescription.para: if non-null, ids to store for the vectors (size n)

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, float radius, RangeSearchResult *result) const
memberdef.name: range_search

detaileddescription.para: query n vectors of dimension d to the index.
return all vectors with distance < radius. Note that many indexes do not implement the range_search (only the k-NN search is mandatory).

parameterdescription.para: input vectors to search, size n * d

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, idx_t *labels, idx_t k=1) const
memberdef.name: assign

detaileddescription.para: return the indexes of the k vectors closest to the query x.

This function is identical as search but only return labels of neighbors.
x
input vectors to search, size n * d
labels
output labels of the NNs, size n*k

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *x, idx_t k, float *distances, idx_t *labels, float *recons) const
memberdef.name: search_and_reconstruct

detaileddescription.para: Similar to search, but also reconstructs the stored vectors (or an approximation in the case of lossy coding) for the search results.
If there are not enough results for a query, the resulting arrays is padded with -1s.

memberdef.argsstring: (const float *x, float *residual, idx_t key) const
memberdef.name: compute_residual

detaileddescription.para: Computes a residual vector after indexing encoding.

The residual vector is the difference between a vector and the reconstruction that can be decoded from its representation in the index. The residual can be used for multiple-stage indexing methods, like IndexIVF's methods.

parameterdescription.para: encoded index, as returned by search and assign

memberdef.argsstring: (idx_t n, const float *xs, float *residuals, const idx_t *keys) const
memberdef.name: compute_residual_n

detaileddescription.para: Computes a residual vector after indexing encoding (batch form). Equivalent to calling compute_residual for each vector.

The residual vector is the difference between a vector and the reconstruction that can be decoded from its representation in the index. The residual can be used for multiple-stage indexing methods, like IndexIVF's methods.

parameterdescription.para: output residual vectors, size (n x d)
encoded index, as returned by search and assign

detaileddescription.para: Index based on a product quantizer. Stored vectors are approximated by PQ codes.
